variants.Description in input context: novel homozygous p.E64D mutation in the DJ1 gene

Material used.Material Name: Patient of Turkish ancestry and his sister
Material used.Description: Dopamine uptake transporter (DAT) binding was measured in the striatum using [18F]FP-CIT and PET.

Readout description.Result Description: Significant reduction in DAT binding in the patient, indicating severe loss of presynaptic dopaminergic neurons.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Normal DAT binding in the striatum (standard values not explicitly described in the literature, inferred from clinical guidelines).

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Significant reduction in DAT binding, indicative of severe dopaminergic neuron loss (standard values not explicitly described in the literature, inferred from clinical guidelines).

Material used.Material Name: HEK293 and COS7 cells overexpressing E64D and L166P mutations
Material used.Description: Cells were transfected with plasmids encoding the E64D and L166P mutations, and protein localization was analyzed via immunocytochemistry.

Readout description.Result Description: 5% of HEK293 cells showed nuclear localization of E64D mutant protein, while 80% of cells showed nuclear localization for L166P mutant protein.

Basic positive control.Description: Wild-type DJ1 protein was used as a positive control for cytoplasmic localization.

Basic negative control.Description: Empty vector-transfected cells were used as a negative control.

Threshold for normal readout.Threshold for normal readout: Cytoplasmic localization of DJ1 protein (standard for wild-type).

Threshold for abnormal readout.Threshold for abnormal readout: Nuclear localization of DJ1 protein (indicative of functional disruption).
